1: <sup>1</sup> Wisdom hath builded her house, she hath hewn out her seven pillars:
2: <sup>2</sup> She hath killed her beasts; she hath mingled her wine; she hath also furnished her table.
3: <sup>3</sup> She hath sent forth her maidens: she crieth upon the highest places of the city,
4: <sup>4</sup> Whoso is simple, let him turn in hither: as for him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,
5: <sup>5</sup> Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine which I have mingled.
6: <sup>6</sup> Forsake the foolish, and live; and go in the way of understanding.
7: <sup>7</sup> He that reproveth a scorner getteth to himself shame: and he that rebuketh a wicked man getteth himself a blot.
8: <sup>8</sup> Reprove not a scorner, lest he hate thee: rebuke a wise man, and he will love thee.
9: <sup>9</sup> Give instruction to a wise man, and he will be yet wiser: teach a just man, and he will increase in learning.
10: <sup>10</sup> The fear of the LORD is the beginning of wisdom: and the knowledge of the holy is understanding.
11: <sup>11</sup> For by me thy days shall be multiplied, and the years of thy life shall be increased.
12: <sup>12</sup> If thou be wise, thou shalt be wise for thyself: but if thou scornest, thou alone shalt bear it.
13: <sup>13</sup> A foolish woman is clamorous: she is simple, and knoweth nothing.
14: <sup>14</sup> For she sitteth at the door of her house, on a seat in the high places of the city,
15: <sup>15</sup> To call passengers who go right on their ways:
16: <sup>16</sup> Whoso is simple, let him turn in hither: and as for him that wanteth understanding, she saith to him,
17: <sup>17</sup> Stolen waters are sweet, and bread eaten in secret is pleasant.
18: <sup>18</sup> But he knoweth not that the dead are there; and that her guests are in the depths of hell.
